A single-component synergistic catalytic system, in which multiple active sites act on a substrate with minimal energy input and promote efficient conversion of the substrate, is considered to be the most advanced technology for simulating enzyme catalytic reaction. The design principles of this technology are the driving force behind the pursuit of cost-effectiveness in industrial production, but the challenges remain formidable. Herein, three periodic mesoporous polyamides with triazine-derived networks (PMP-TDNs) were prepared via "one-pot" polycondensation, and used as non-metallic catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides without any additives to synthesis cyclic carbonates. The composition and physicochemical properties of PMP-TDNs were evaluated via different analytical methods to explore the crucial factors affecting catalytic activity. Especially, the activity of PMP-TDNs-MI with multiple hydrogen bond donor (HBD) and high-density N basic sites have been tested effectually; the results has demonstrated a superior reactivity for the cycloaddition of CO2 and a wide range of epoxides with reusability. The kinetics and thermodynamics of cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene epoxide by PMP-TDNS-MI were investigated, and the cooperative catalytic mechanism between the versatile active sites of catalyst was revealed based on the experimental results. Graphical Abstract CO2 fixation to cyclic carbonates: We reported a novel triazinyl-imidazole HBD catalyst (PMP-TDNs-MI) that exhibited superior activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides (yield up to 99.9%), without any additives and with reusability. ga1 Keywords CO2 utilization Triazinyl-imidazole derivatives Hydrogen bonding Non-metal catalysis Recyclable catalyst 1 Introduction In view of the environmental issues caused by carbon dioxide (CO2), the capture and chemical utilization of CO2 are indeed the effective ways to pursue a sustainable development and meet growing energy demands [1–3]. Among the ways, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide to produce cyclic carbonate is 100% atom-economic [4]. Due to the high polarity and bioactivities, the cyclic carbonate has been widely employed in electrolytes for lithium batteries, fuel additives, polymer synthesis and intermediates for pharmaceuticals/fine chemicals etc. [5–8]. Unfortunately, because of the inherent thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia of CO2 [9], effective catalysts have to be introduced to reduce the energy barriers for industrial production of cyclic carbonates [4]. Recently, hydrogen bond donor (HBD) catalysts, a type of catalyst with functional groups such as -NH-/-NH2, -OH and -COOH in their chemical structures, are becoming a hotspot in academic researches [5,10–12]. In terms of mechanism, HBD effectively polarized the C-O bond of epoxide through the H-bond formed after binding with O of epoxide, thereby the ring-opening of epoxide is promoted [10,13,14]. Meanwhile, CO2 is adsorbed and activated by Lewis basic sites (e.g., -N= and -N-H) in catalyst before participating in cycloaddition [5,10]. In this process, the capability of catalyst to reduce the reaction potential barrier depends on its strength of interaction with CO2/epoxide, in which the ring-opening of epoxide is the decisive step of the reaction [13,14]. Compared with widely used catalysts that essentially contain metals/halides, such as alkali metal halides [15,16], organometallic complexes [8,17], metal-organic frameworks [4,18], porous organic framework [19], ionic liquids with halogens [20,21], etc., functionalized HBD catalysts can effectively replace the ring-opening effect of Lewis acid metal ions or Lewis alkali halides (nucleophilic attack), with pleasurable catalytic performance. Moreover, functionalized HBD catalysts can make up for some disadvantages of traditional multi-component catalysts, such as the corrosion of reactor caused by alkaline halides, and metal leaching/residual of catalyst in products due to its poor thermal/chemical stability [8,13,22]. Triazine-based polymer materials with aromatic triazine rings as building units have unique properties such as N-rich, conjugated and sturdy heterocyclic aromatic CN skeleton, as well as structural rigidity, low skeleton density, expanded network with adjustable porosity and high thermal/chemical stability [9,23,24]. And they have been widely studied and applied in the fields of heterogeneous catalysis [24,25], gas adsorption/separation [23,26], and energy storage [27]. Polyamide is a kind of high-performance thermoplastic material that mainly employed in national defense and aerospace because of its outstanding chemical resistance, excellent mechanical properties and high thermal stability. These characteristics are mainly attributed to the rigid structure of functional polyamide and intermolecular strong H-bond of the tight chain stacking [28,29]. It has been reported that the polymer frameworks which contain a large number of N and O heteroatoms can form a strong dipole-quadrupole interaction with CO2 [29,30]. Apart from the characteristics stated above, another essential one is that the amide bonds with binary interaction sites (CO and N-H) in the polyamides also meet the H-bond interaction, Lewis acid/base interaction, etc. [26,29,31]. The enzyme-like catalysts with multi-functional synergy and high catalytic activity are pursued by scientists, however, it is difficult to obtain, meanwhile the chemical structure of amide bond in polyamide is similar to that of peptide bond in enzyme [4,32]. Therefore, it is theoretically feasible to design and prepare polyamides with synergistic active sites, especially aromatic triazinyl polyamides. This is caused by the fact that non-metal versatile catalysts for epoxide and CO2 cycloaddition is undoubtedly a fascinating field with just a few reports in this regard. Herein, a kind of periodic and triazine-derived mesoporous polyamides (PMP-TDNs) with multiple HBD groups and high-density N-basic sites (from amide, triazene ring, and imidazole) was designed, it can meet the versatility requirements for epoxide polarized ring-opening and CO2 adsorption/activation ( Scheme 1). The composition and physicochemical properties of PMP-TDNs were exhaustively evaluated through different analytical methods to explore the key factors that affect catalytic effects. In particular, PMP-TDNs-MI, as a novel non-metal heterogeneous catalyst, had been efficiently tested; and it had demonstrated its superior activity for the cycloaddition of CO2 with a wide range of epoxides without any co-catalyst and solvent, together with fulfills the environmental requirements and green production processes. Moreover, PMP-TDNs-MI was proved to have high recoverability and cycle stability. The kinetics and thermodynamics of cycloaddition of CO2 with PO by PMP-TDNS-MI were further studied, and the synergistic catalytic mechanism between the multifunctional active sites of the catalyst was revealed based on the experimental results. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals 4,5-Imidazoledicarboxylic acid (4,5-IDCA, 97%), 2,5-thiophenedicarboxylic acid (2,5-TDCA, 98%), melamine (MA, 99%), 4-aminobenzonitrile (4-AB, 98%), p-dioxane (99.5%), 4-dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP, 99%), HATU (99%), triflic acid (98%), dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, AR), chloroform-d (CDCl3, 0.03% TMS), dimethylsulfoxide-d6 (DMSO-d6, 0.03% TMS) and epoxides were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Inc. Carbon dioxide (99.999%) was purchased from Kunming guangruida Special Gas Co., Ltd. N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF, AR), N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA, AR), ammonia solution (AR, 25%), CH2Cl2 (AR) and methanol (AR) were obtained from Xilong Scientific Co., Ltd. All chemicals were used directly. 2.2 Materials synthesis 2.2.1 Preparation of PMP-TDNs-MI Typically, the mixture of MA (2.522 g, 20.0 mmol), 4,5-IDCA (4.683 g, 30.0 mmol) and DMAP (0.305 g, 2.5 mmol) in p-dioxane (93.4 mL) were added into a flask and then stirred at 110 ℃ for 30 h before cooling to ambient temperature. Next, the resulting beige-paste solid product was filtered and washed with dimethyl sulfoxide and methanol for several times and vacuum dried under 110 ℃ for 12 h. 2.2.2 Preparation of PMP-TDNs-MT A mixture of MA (2.522 g, 20.0 mmol), 2,5-TDCA (5.165 g, 30.0 mmol), DMAP (0.305 g, 2.5 mmol) and HATU (0.951 g, 2.5 mmol) and DMF (77.3 mL) was placed in a flask and then stirred under room temperature for 10 h, and the post-treatment of the white solid product obtained was consistent with PMP-TDNs-MI. 2.2.3 Preparation of PMP-TDNs-TI A mixture of TAPT (1.772 g, 5.0 mmol), 4,5-IDCA (1.171 g, 7.5 mmol), DMAP (0.305 g, 2.5 mmol), HATU (0.475 g, 1.25 mmol) and DMA (116.8 mL) was introduced into a flask and then stirred at 140 ℃ for 48 h. The reacted brown liquid mixture was evaporated to remove the solvent, and the post-treatment of the brown solid obtained was consistent with the above. Herein, TAPT was synthesized according to the previous reports with slight modifications [33]. 2.3 Characterization Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded from a Bruker-Vertex 70 V instrument. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were performed on a Bruker-Avance-III-HD with TMS as internal standard (600 and 151 MHz). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were evaluated using a Thermo-Fisher-ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) were measured on an X-ray Cu Ka radiation diffractometer to determine solid-state structure (UltimaIV, 40 KV, 40 mA, 0.15406 nm). The element content was derived from Elemantar-Vario-EL cube. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) was carried out on a Nova-Nano SEM450, and its elemental mapping was operated at 15 kV. Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was estimated through N2 adsorption/desorption data analysis at − 195.85 °C (ASAP 2460). Pore volume and pore diameter distribution curves were obtained from the adsorption branches using Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a NETZSCH TG 209F3 instrument under N2 flow from 30° to 800 °C (10 °C/min). 2.4 Typical procedures for CO2 cycloaddition and catalyst recyclability For a typical run, a mixture of epoxide (50 mmol) and catalyst (61.3 mg) was placed in a sealed stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) and the autoclave was then purged with CO2 for three times. Next, the mixture was stirred at 1.0 MPa CO2 pressure and 80–120 ℃ temperature for a designated period ( Table 1). After the reaction, the reactor was cooled with an ice bath, and the gas was released slowly [34]. The catalyst was then centrifuged, and the product yield was confirmed by 1H NMR analysis [7,32]. Eventually, the catalyst collected by filtration was rinsed with CH2Cl2 for several times and reused directly after vacuum drying at 60 ℃ for 8 h. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts Chemical confirmation of prepared materials was given through FT-IR NMR, XPS ( Fig. 1(a-d)). The new characteristic stretching vibrations of N-H/-OH/-CO-NH- and -CO-NH- of three catalysts occurred at 3465–3010 and 1558–1522 cm−1, respectively, and typical amide carbonyl CO stretching was also observed at 1686–1653 cm−1 [29,35,36]. Meanwhile, -COOH and -NH2 absorption peaks of the corresponding monomers (provided in Figs. S1–3) were not detected in prepared catalysts, and this indicated that catalysts were successfully synthesized by forming amide bond -CO-NH- (Fig. 1(a)) [26,33,35–38]. The structure of the prepared catalysts was presented in detail by NMR spectra (Fig. 1(b-c)). The new resonance signal emerges at 7.73 ppm, which indicated the hydrogen atoms H3 of amide bond of PMP-TDNs-MI (Fig. 1(b)). Chemical shifts corresponding to the hydrogen atoms of -NH2 of MA and -COOH of 4,5-IDCA (active H was not detected but was reported to be about 13–14 ppm) were not observed in PMP-TDNs-MI (provided in Fig. S4) [35,39,40]. 1H NMR results also verified the condensation occurred between -NH2 and -COOH. Chemical shifts of C4 (CO) and C5 of PMP-TDNs-MI were detected at 139.65 and 162.56 ppm, respectively (Fig. 1(c)) [35,41,42]. Moreover, resonance signals of C4 and C5 of PMP-TDNs-MI were moved to higher fields obviously compared with monomers 4,5-IDCA at 159.76 ppm and MA at 167.86 ppm, respectively (Fig. S5) [10,41,42]. This may be ascribed to p-π conjugated system that was formed in amide bond by π-electron of carbonyl and lone-pair electrons of amino N atoms (sp2 hybrid), which also confirmed the successful occurrence of the amide bond [43]. Similar results were also obtained in the NMR spectra of other catalysts (Fig. 1(b-c) and Figs. S4 and 5). The surface chemical configurations were examined by XPS (Fig. 1(d) and Fig. S6). The N 1 s peaks of three materials were resolved into two components, including the amide moiety -NH-CO- (400.68–399.58 eV) and triazine skeleton nitrogen N-CN (398.08–398.48 eV) (Fig. 1(d)) [26,37,44]. The appearance of amide moiety -NH- bond was strongly consistent with the results of FT-IR and 1H NMR. The FE-SEM was subsequently performed to investigate the morphology of the obtained catalysts ( Fig. 2(a-c)). Obviously, PMP-TDNs-MI was composed by staggered aggregation of regular smooth flakes in contrast to PMP-TDNs-MT which showed an ordered sawdust fiber structure. PMP-TDNs-TI revealed the existence of interconnected, uniform and rough surfaces, also plentiful and hierarchical porosities [21]. The uniform distribution of all functional elements (C, N, O) was verified via elemental mapping FE-SEM (Fig. 2(d-f)). This indicated that the active functional sites of all catalysts had excellent integration, it also implied that they are conducive to the CO2 conversion process [21]. From PXRD spectrum in Fig. 2(g), all catalysts still displayed sharp and clear narrow diffraction peaks after cyclization reaction, the results indicated higher crystallinity and more long-range ordered structure. The results of PXRD illustrated that the formed polyamide chains were effectively closed and packed to form polyamide networks. In addition, these polyamide networks had a more homogeneous chemical environment which was consistent with the surface morphology in Fig. 2(a-c) [45,46]. In particular, a typical (002) plane exhibited in all catalysts, which can be indexed to the packing characteristics of the interlayer structure of triazine networks [22,47]. Meanwhile, a new (200) facet occurred in all catalysts compared with their monomers, which may be related to the active hydroxyl group in enol structure (obtained by amide bond tautomerism) (Figs. S7–9) [5,43,48]. After that, the N2 adsorption/desorption analysis for the textural properties of all catalysts were measured (Fig. 2(h)). Notably, a typical reversible type-IV N2 sorption isotherm with an H3 hysteresis loop was observed in all catalysts, and their N2 uptake increased rapidly only at relatively higher pressure (0.6 <P/P0 <1.0), especially PMP-TDNs-TI, representing the existence of mesoporous with interparticle voids in all catalysts [10,29]. Their pore size distribution and average pore diameter (9.27–17.99 nm) further confirmed a finding that they were dominated by mesopores (Fig. 2(h), Table S1, ESI†) [10,44]. In general, the existence of mesoporous structure can promote the mass transfer of reactants and products, which was conducive to improving the catalytic efficiency [49]. Indeed, PMP-TDNs-TI possessed higher BET surface area (47.99 m2/g) with total pore volume (0.19 cm³/g) as compared to PMP-TDNs-MI and PMP-TDNs-MT (Table S1, ESI†), owing to the inherent porosity produced the TAPT monomer (a triazine-ring skeleton linked by benzene-rings result in a larger extended network structure). While the low level of porosity for PMP-TDNs-MI and PMP-TDNs-MT may also be ascribed to the strong interaction between amide bonds/imidazole-ring with triazine-skeleton layers through massive intramolecular and intermolecular H-bonds donated by the hydrazine cross-linking (Table S1, ESI†) [9,35,43]. The TGA curve revealed that a sharp weight loss (87.46 wt%) caused by thermal degradation of the main chemical structure of PMP-TDNs-MI at 275–326 ℃ (Step II). Only 2.16 wt% initial weight loss at 20–275 ℃ (Step I) was attributed to the solvent or moisture adsorbed by the material (Fig. S10) [50,51]. This favorable thermal stability was derived from the stable conjugated structure/system formed by heat-resistant amide bond, triazine-ring skeleton and imidazole-ring in polyamide network, which illustrated the upper limit temperature (≤275 ℃) of the material for catalytic reaction [26,35]. 3.2 Evaluate the catalytic activity of various materials employed in CO2 cycloaddition After confirming the structure of all catalysts, the activity of all catalysts for the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO as a model was tested ( Fig. 3 and Table 1). With the results from Table 1, almost all other catalyst monomers exhibited lower catalytic activity except 4,5-IDCA (Table 1, entries 2–5). With the comparison of the chemical structures of the four monomers, it can be found that there was only one single HBD (-COOH or -NH2) in the structures of 2,5-TDCA, TAPT and MA, however, 4,5-IDCA possessed three HBD groups including -COOH, -NH and =C-H (especially, the induction and conjugation effects formed by π electrons of large electronegative N atoms in imidazole-ring lead to the more active H in -NH and =C-H, showing obvious acidity) [43,52]. From the perspective of mechanism, the above HBD groups can be combined with the O of epoxide to form a H-bond to promote the ring-opening of epoxide [9,10]. In addition, TAPT, MA and 4,5-IDCA also with imine groups (-N= ) from triazene-ring or imidazole-ring can provide Lewis N basic sites for CO2 adsorption and activation compared to 2,5-TDCA [11,26]. Both the ring-opening of epoxide and the activation of CO2 were crucial in the whole cycloaddition, in which the ring-opening of epoxide was the rate-determining step [13,14]. This also explains why 2,5-TDCA monomer with only a single HBD (-COOH) and no Lewis N basic site possessed the worst catalytic effect, while 4,5-IDCA had the best. To test the assumption that more types of HBDs and imines were more beneficial to improving catalytic effect, the monomers were mixed physically. Their monomers mixtures also revealed relatively poor activity in cycloaddition (Table 1, entries 6–8) may be attributed to the physical mixing of their monomers without provision of a porous for the adsorption, storage and further efficient activation of CO2. The materials had unique properties of porosity, so as to better enhance CO2 adsorption capacity [49]. To verify the advantages of porous materials, the activity of three PMP-TDNs catalysts were tested. Combined with the above characterization results, the catalytic activities of three PMP-TDNs catalysts with mesoporous structure were better than their monomers or mixtures except PMP-TDNs-MT (Table 1, entries 9–12). This superior rule was consistent with the relevant literature, which meant that the mesoporous structure and excellent dispersion of the materials allowed more catalytic active sites to contact with reactants, and promoted mass and heat transfer, thus higher catalytic efficiency were produced [49,53]. Abnormally, PMP-TDNs-MT still showed poor activity even though it was a mesoporous material, the reason may be caused by its single HBD from amide bond and the weak electronegativity of S (S<N) in the conjugated and stable aromatic thiophene-ring results in no contribution to HBD activity [38]. According to the results in Table S1, PMP-TDNs-MT with poor BET surface area (BET: 4.18 m2/g) makes it also unfavorable for full contact with reactants. However, despite the inferior BET surface area/porosity (BET: 7.69 m2/g) of PMP-TDNs-MI, the catalytic activity of PMP-TDNs-MI was much better than that of PMP-TDNs-TI. This abnormal result may reasonable if considering that PMP-TDNs-MI with imidazole-ring, triazine skeleton and amide bond would have an extremely high N component (34.34 N%, from elemental analysis, Table S2), and CO2 adsorption and activation were promoted by dipole-quadrupole interactions between the abundant N basic sites and the polarizable CO2 [29,30]. In contrast, PMP-TDNs-TI was composed of non-polar benzene rings, which may also contribute to its weak surface chemical force to CO2 [26]. On the other hand, it can also be explained by the high π delocalization effect of the benzene ring in PMP-TDNs-TI. Due to the high delocalization of π electrons, the N-H in amide bond tended to favor the benzene ring and weaken the amide bond to activate the epoxides through H-bond, resulting in the reduction of electron cloud density of N-H [54–56]. Thus, the superior catalytic efficiency of PMP-TDNs-MI for CO2 cycloaddition was the result of the combined effect from several factors: multiple types of HBD groups (from amide N-H, imidazole N-H and =C-H), especially the excessive acidity of the amide N-H or imidazole N-H (due to the presence of the triazene ring or imidazole ring) may have played a crucial role in forming a strong H-bond with epoxide [43,52]; multi-function N-rich basic sites (from amide, triazene ring and imidazole); absence of inert groups (not rewarding for cycloaddition) and long-range ordered mesoporous environment for enhanced molecular diffusion [57]. PMP-TDNs-MI was compared with some metal-free heterogeneous catalysts reported in the literature to verify the superiority of PMP-TDNs-MI (see Table S3 for details). From the results in Table S3, it can be seen that metal-free carbon material catalysts (Table S3, entries 1–3), biological catalysts (Table S3, entries 4–6), ionic liquids catalysts (Table S3, entries 7–8), porous/mesoporous organic polymer catalysts (Table S3, entries 9–10), etc. also exhibited relatively good activities for cycloaddition of CO2 with PO. But in general, in order to achieve better conversion/yield, the above-mentioned catalysts were used inevitably under high temperature (Table S3, entries 1–2, 4–5, 9 and 11) or high pressure (Table S3, entries 1 and 6) conditions, by using halides (Table S3, entries 6 and 10–12) and toxic solvents (Table S3, entry 2), and in large dosage (Table S3, entry 5). In contrast, PMP-TDNs-MI had remarkable catalytic activity, with the advantages of small dosage, mild reaction conditions, no involvement of halides and solvents, and easy preparation. 3.3 Catalytic activity of PMP-TDNs-MI for CO2 and various epoxides Encouraged by the excellent catalytic activity of PMP-TDNs-MI in the above-mentioned CO2/PO cycloaddition, the universality of PMP-TDNs-MI was further investigated ( Table 2). Obviously, the steric hindrance and electronic effect of the tested epoxides terminal substituents affected the efficiency of the self-cycloaddition [58]. The reactivity of epoxide linked to electron-withdrawing group (Table 2, a-b) was better than that of epoxide linked to electron-donating substituent, owing to the electron-withdrawing group decreased the electron cloud density of Cβ-O bond of its alkene-ring and assisted the ring opening of H-bond polarized epoxides [11]. For aliphatic terminal substrates with electron-donating groups, the reactivity decreases as the extension of the side-chain substituent carbon chain (the higher the steric hindrance) (Table 2, c-f, i) [59]. In contrast, the relatively positive reactivity for the epoxide corresponding to ‘f’ may be attributed to the high electronegativity of O atoms in the long carbon chain, which can attract the electron cloud of adjacent groups, thereby promoting the ring-opening rate (Table 2, f) [5]. Excitingly, the terminal substrates with large molecular size, rigidity and bulky aromatic ring also obtained a higher yield (Table 2, g-h). This highlights the superiority of the polyamide mesoporous network channels for the cycloaddition, which was not greatly affected by the size of the reactants [4]. The by-products of epoxides with CO2 by cycloaddition may be polycarbonates, polyethers, aldehydes or ketones [60–62]. Since cyclic carbonates are more thermodynamically stable, it is more favorable to form cyclic carbonates at relatively higher temperatures. By-products such as polycarbonates or polyethers are more readily produced at low temperature, while aldehydes or ketones are derived from the isomerization of epoxides at high temperatures [63,64]. Here, side product (low selectivity) generated by cycloaddition of isobutene oxide with CO2 can be assigned to isobutyraldehyde which was an isomerization product of isobutene oxide at 110 °C ( Table 2, i) [62]. As an exception, cyclohexane oxide still had a low conversion after 60 h due to the hindered of large steric hindrance from the six-membered inner ring structure (Table 2, j) [58,65]. Overall, PMP-TDNs-MI successfully converted most of the various epoxides tested with high efficiency. 3.4 Kinetic and thermodynamic studies The kinetics of PMP-TDNs-MI in different recycling runs for cycloaddition of PO with CO2 were explored. The rate equation was described by Eq. (1) and simplified Eq. (2) [57]. (1) rate = -d[PO]/dt = k[PO] a [CO2] b [Catalyst] c (2) rate = -d[PO]/dt = k obs[PO] a , where k obs = k[CO2] b [Catalyst] c In the above equations, a, b and c means the reactant order, while k obs and k represent the pseudo 1st order rate constant and rate constant, respectively. Here, the reaction process was assumed to follow 1st order, and the rate equation was reduced to Eq. (3) and its logarithmic integral Eq. (4) [14,66]. As shown in Fig. 4(a-c), the kinetic curves of PO conversion versus time under different temperature showed that increasing temperature had a significant positive effect on catalyst activity. Because the variation of -Ln[PO] with time conforms to a linear relationship, this further verified that the entire reaction process meets the 1st order kinetics (Fig. 4(d-f)). (3) rate = -d[PO]/dt = k obs[PO]1 (4) -Ln[PO] = k obs t (5) k obs = A e -Ea/(RT) (6) Lnk obs = -E a /(RT) + Ln A Activation energy (E a , kJ∙mol−1) was then obtained by the Arrhenius Eqs. (5–6) [57], where R, A and T denote the universal gas constant (8.314 J∙mol−1K−1), pre-exponential factor (min−1) and absolute temperature (K), respectively. From the fitting equation in Fig. 4(g) and Arrhenius Eq. (6), E a = 68.3203 kJ∙mol−1 and A = 1.78 × 107 min−1 were obtained for PO/CO2 cycloaddition catalyzed by PMP-TDNs-MI-R1 in the scope of 363–393 K. Thus, the kinetic equation was written as: rate = -d[PO]/dt = 1.78 × 107 e −68.32/(RT)[PO]. In addition, the activation energies of PMP-TDNs-MI-R3 and PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 were increased to 74.9244 kJ∙mol−1 and 76.1328 kJ∙mol−1, respectively; their pre-exponential factors were increased to 7.03 × 107 min−1 and 8.83 × 107 min−1, respectively. This indicated that the activity (initial rates) of PMP-TDNs-MI gradually decayed after the 3rd and 5th recycling runs. The thermodynamic of cycloaddition was then investigated with Eyring Eq. (7) and its integral Eqs. (8–9) [67]. (7) k obs = (k BT/h)exp(-ΔG/RT) = (k BT/h)exp(-ΔH/RT + ΔS/R) (8) Ln(k obs/T) = -ΔH/(RT) + Ln (k B/h) + ΔS/R (9) TLn(k obs/T) = (Ln (k B/h) + ΔS/R)T-ΔH/R Where k B denotes the Boltzmann’s constant (k B = 1.38065 ×10−23 J·K−1), h means the Planck's constant (h = 6.62608 ×10−34 J·s), whereas ΔG, ΔH and ΔS represent activation Gibbs free energy, activation enthalpy and activation entropy, respectively. As shown by the linear fitting in Fig. 4(h-i), the values of ΔH (66.5594 kJ∙mol−1) and ΔS (−0.1165 kJ∙mol−1) of PMP-TDNs-MI-R1 can be determined through Eqs. (7) and (8), respectively. Finally, the ΔG values (111.1718–108.8422 kJ∙mol−1) of PMP-TDNs-MI-R1 were calculated from ΔG = ΔH-TΔS under different temperatures (393–363 K). All the ΔH, ΔS and ΔG values of PMP-TDNs-MI-R3 and PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 were increased compared to PMP-TDNs-MI-R1 (see Table S4 for details). From the above results, the values of ΔH> 0 and ΔG> 0 indicated that the cycloaddition of epoxides and CO2 catalyzed by PMP-TDNs-MI was kinetic controlled and irreversible. However, ΔS< 0 showed the activated epoxides tend to develop in an orderly. 3.5 Reaction mechanism The presence of amide bonds, imidazole and triazene ring in the polyamide network gave PMP-TDNs-MI multi-directional HBD capability and Lewis basic, which were critical in the ring-opening of epoxide and CO2 adsorption/activation. Based on the above spectral evidence, the mechanism of synergistic catalytic activation between versatile H-bonds and N basic sites was speculated ( Fig. 5(a-c)). Firstly, amide N-H, imidazole N-H and =C-H of PMP-TDNs-MI, as HBD groups, formed H-bonds (-N-H…O and =C-H…O) by combining with O in the epoxy-ring [7,10]. These H-bonds caused Cβ-O bond with less steric hindrance and lower extranuclear electron cloud density of epoxy-ring to become polarized and ring broken, further forming activated epoxide intermediate [9,10]. Notably, the excessive acidity of the amide N-H or imidazole N-H caused by the presence of the triazene ring or imidazole ring may have played an essential role in forming strong H-bonds with epoxide [43,52]. Furthermore, the polarization ability of H-bonds was enhanced by another HBD (CO…H or =N…H) through intramolecular or intermolecular association of a highly electronegative carbonyl O or imine N atoms with H in the adjacent HBD [35,68,69]. FT-IR in Fig. 5(a) provided some evidence for the above elaboration. When the catalyst acted on PO, the characteristic peaks of -NH/-CO-NH- in catalyst were red-shifted from 3446 to 3419 cm−1 and the sharp peak at 3446 cm−1 also disappeared/broadened, indicating that -NH participate in H-bonding (Fig. 5(a), PMP-TDNs-MI + CO2 + PO, PMP-TDNs-MI + PO) [70]. Meanwhile, 1H NMR spectra also verified this interesting result, and H atoms signals in catalyst were transferred from H1 and H3 to H1' and H3' to varying degrees respectively, after H-bonding occurred (Fig. 5(b), PMP-TDNs-MI + CO2 + PO, PMP-TDNs-MI + PO) [71]. In addition, N of -N= or -NH with edge defects derived from polar triazine, imidazole and amide bond provided rich Lewis basic sites, which synergistically promoted CO2 physicochemical affinity, thus the results greatly enhanced CO2 adsorption and activation [5,11,29]. The new signal at 1716 cm−1 in FT-IR was attributed to the asymmetric vibration of carbamate produced after the catalyst was applied to CO2 alone, thus this confirmed the above view (Fig. 5(a), PMP-TDNs-MI + CO2) [58]. The epoxide then activated the Cβ + of the intermediate to attack the activated CO2 oxygen anion to form the carbonate hemiester compound [13]. Subsequently, linear carbonate hemiester compounds underwent intramolecular nucleophilic attack, further "backbiting" closed-loop cyclization [11]. Eventually, the formed cyclic carbonate was broken from the weakened H-bond and desorbed from the N adsorption site, while the catalyst was regenerated and entered the next cycle. Here, the rate-determining step in the whole cycloaddition was the ring-opening of epoxide. The cooperative effect between the multifunctional H-bonds and high density N-basic sites in PMP-TDNs-MI polyamide network effectively promoted the cycloaddition. 3.6 Recycling of PMP-TDNs-MI One of the advantages of PMP-TDNs-MI was the excellent separability benefited from its heterogeneous nature. The results in Fig. S11(a) displayed that PMP-TDNs-MI still had pleasurable catalytic activity after 5 recycling. The recycled catalyst was then deeply studied by comparative analysis. FT-IR NMR and XPS results revealed that PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 still maintained the basic chemical configuration, except for the slight shift of the peak position possibly due to the participation in hydrogen bonding, and the new peak caused by product residue (Fig. S11(b-e)) [70,71]. From the results of PXRD, some changes in the peaks of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 compared with PMP-TDNs-MI may be attributed to the destruction of part of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 structure caused by the strong stirring during repeated use [72]. Here, the (200) facet related to the active OH in the enol was significantly reduced, which may be due to the fact that the partial amide bond of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 was broken, resulting in the inability to form the enol structure through tautomerism (Fig. S11(f)) [5,43,48]. The decreased BET, pore size, and pore volume of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 compared with PMP-TDNs-MI (Table S1, entries 1 and 4) may be caused by the retention of a small amount of products to be difficultly removed in the mesoporous channels of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5. Occupation of catalytic active sites by the residual products in the channels affect the mass and heat transfer during the reaction process, resulting in the loss of activity. The element analysis of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 showed that the N content of main active sites had little reduced compared with PMP-TDNs-MI, indicating that the decay of activity might be caused by the leaching of main active sites in the catalytic and post-treatment process. In addition, the changes of C, O and H contents of PMP-TDNs-MI-R5 may also be related to the residual products (Table S2, entries 1 and 4). Overall, the activity reduction of recovered PMP-TDNs-MI was associated to the following factors: 1) Occupation of active sites by product residues in mesoporous channels affected mass and heat transfer; 2) strong stirring resulted in partial decomposition of skeleton structure; 3) partial leaching of the main active sites, etc. 4 Conclusions Three polyamides networks (PMP-TDNs) were presented and their activities for CO2 cycloaddition were investigated. PMP-TDNs-MI, as a novel HBD catalyst, exhibited superior activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 with 10 epoxides (yield ~99.9%), with no involvement of halides and solvents. The remarkable catalytic efficiency of PMP-TDNs-MI for CO2 cycloaddition was attributed to the following factors: 1) synergistic effect through multiple HBD capabilities and N-rich basic active sites; 2) absence of inert groups; 3) an ordered mesoporous environment. Furthermore, the good thermal/chemical stability and the reusability of PMP-TDNs-MI represented a great advantage for industrial CO2 cycloaddition. coredata.dc:description: A single-component synergistic catalytic system, in which multiple active sites act on a substrate with minimal energy input and promote efficient conversion of the substrate, is considered to be the most advanced technology for simulating enzyme catalytic reaction. The design principles of this technology are the driving force behind the pursuit of cost-effectiveness in industrial production, but the challenges remain formidable. Herein, three periodic mesoporous polyamides with triazine-derived networks (PMP-TDNs) were prepared via "one-pot" polycondensation, and used as non-metallic catalysts for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides without any additives to synthesis cyclic carbonates. The composition and physicochemical properties of PMP-TDNs were evaluated via different analytical methods to explore the crucial factors affecting catalytic activity. Especially, the activity of PMP-TDNs-MI with multiple hydrogen bond donor (HBD) and high-density N basic sites have been tested effectually; the results has demonstrated a superior reactivity for the cycloaddition of CO2 and a wide range of epoxides with reusability. The kinetics and thermodynamics of cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene epoxide by PMP-TDNS-MI were investigated, and the cooperative catalytic mechanism between the versatile active sites of catalyst was revealed based on the experimental results.
coredata.dc:title: Triazinyl-imidazole polyamide network as an efficient multi-hydrogen bond donor catalyst for additive-free CO2 cycloaddition
